a.g: [This is] a surah which We have sent down and made [that within it] obligatory and revealed therein verses of clear evidence that you might remember.

The [unmarried] woman or [unmarried] man found guilty of sexual intercourse - lash each one of them with a hundred lashes, and do not be taken by pity for them in the religion of Allah, if you should believe in Allah and the Last Day. And let a group of the believers witness their punishment.

Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

ğŸ“– Vol 3: Condemnation of Anger and Envy
And from the weakness of anger (Ghadab) is cowardice (Khur) and silence when witnessing reprehensible acts (Munkarat), and the Prophet (peace be upon him) said: 'The best of my community are those with anger (Ahda'uha),' meaning in religion. And Allah the Exalted said: 'And let not pity (Ra'fah) for them take hold of you in the religion of Allah.' Rather, whoever loses anger is incapable of disciplining (Riyadah) his Soul (Nafs), for discipline is not accomplished except by unleashing anger upon desire (Shahwah), so that he becomes angry with himself when inclining towards base desires. Thus, the loss of anger is blameworthy, and only the praiseworthy anger is that which awaits the signal of intellect (Aql) and religion (Din), so it arises where zeal (Hamiyyah) is required and extinguishes where forbearance (Hilm) is appropriate. Maintaining it at the limit of moderation (I'tidal) is the uprightness (Istiqamah) that Allah has obligated upon His servants, and it is the middle path (Wasat) that the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) described when he said: 'The best of matters are their middle ones.' So whoever's anger leans towards feebleness until he feels from himself weakness of zeal (Ghayrah) and baseness of the Soul (Nafs) in enduring humiliation (Dhull) and oppression (Daym) in its improper place, then he should treat himself until his anger strengthens.

a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

Vol 2: Etiquette of Sama and Wajd
Indeed, whoever is overpowered by grief [huzn] or longing [shawq] or regret [nadam], then from where does the state of the one who says, "And those who accuse chaste women..." [Quran 24:4]â€”and likewise all the verses which contain the clarification of the rulings of inheritance, divorce, prescribed punishments, and other mattersâ€”suit his condition? For the only thing that stirs what is in the heart [qalb] is what corresponds to it. And the verses of poetry are only placed by the poets as an expression of the states of the heart [qalb], so there is no need for contrivance in understanding the state from them. Yes, whoever is overpowered by a dominant, overwhelming state [halah] that leaves no room for anything else within him, and he possesses with it an alertness and a penetrating, keen intelligence [dhaka'] by which he perceives the distant meanings from the words, then his spiritual passion [wajd] may be stirred by everything heard. Like the one for whom it occurs, upon the mention of His saying, the Most High, "And those who accuse chaste women..." [Quran 24:4]. So the likes of this one may stir spiritual passion [wajd]. But only for the one in whom are two attributes: the first, a dominant, all-encompassing, overwhelming state [halah]; and the second, a profound perceptiveness [tafattun] and a complete, intense alertness [yaqazah] for being alerted by proximate matters to distant meanings. And that is rare. Therefore, for that reason, one resorts to song [ghina'], which consists of words suitable for the states [ahwal], so that their agitation may be hastened.

a.g: Except for those who repent thereafter and reform, for indeed, Allah is Forgiving and Merciful.

And those who accuse their wives [of adultery] and have no witnesses except themselves - then the witness of one of them [shall be] four testimonies [swearing] by Allah that indeed, he is of the truthful.
And the fifth [oath will be] that the curse of Allah be upon him if he should be among the liars.
But it will prevent punishment from her if she gives four testimonies [swearing] by Allah that indeed, he is of the liars.
And the fifth [oath will be] that the wrath of Allah be upon her if he was of the truthful.
And if not for the favor of Allah upon you and His mercy... and because Allah is Accepting of repentance and Wise.

Indeed, those who came with falsehood are a group among you. Do not think it bad for you; rather it is good for you. For every person among them is what [punishment] he has earned from the sin, and he who took upon himself the greater portion thereof - for him is a great punishment.
Why, when you heard it, did not the believing men and believing women think good of one another and say, "This is an obvious falsehood"?
Why did they [who slandered] not produce for it four witnesses? And when they do not produce the witnesses, then it is they, in the sight of Allah, who are the liars.
And if it had not been for the favor of Allah upon you and His mercy in this world and the Hereafter, you would have been touched for that [lie] in which you were involved by a great punishment
When you received it with your tongues and said with your mouths that of which you had no knowledge and thought it was insignificant while it was, in the sight of Allah, tremendous.

ğŸ“– Vol 4: Patience and Gratitude
If you say: How can I rejoice when I see a group whose disobedience has increased beyond my disobedience, and they have not been afflicted with what I have been afflicted with, even the disbelievers? Then know that for the disbeliever, what is greater has been stored away, and he is only given respite so that he may increase in sin and his punishment may be prolonged, as Allah the Exalted said: 'We only give them respite so that they may increase in sin' (Quran 3:178). As for the disobediences, from where do you know that in the world there is one who is more disobedient than him? And perhaps a thought of bad manners (sÅ«' adab) in the right of Allah the Exalted and in His attributes is greater and more severe than drinking wine, fornication, and all other disobediences with the limbs. And for that reason, Allah the Exalted said regarding its like: 'And you consider it trivial, while it is, with Allah, immense' (Quran 24:15). From where do you know that others are more disobedient than you? Then perhaps his punishment has been delayed to the Hereafter, and your punishment has been hastened in this world, so why do you not thank Allah the Exalted for that? And this is the third aspect in thankfulness (shukr), which is that there is no punishment except that it can be imagined to be delayed to the Hereafter. And the afflictions of this world are consoled by other means that lighten the affliction, so its impact is lessened. But the affliction of the Hereafter endures, and if it does not endure, then there is no way to alleviate it by consolation, since the means of consolation are completely cut off in the Hereafter for the tormented. And whoever's punishment is hastened in this world is not punished a second time, as the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: 'Indeed, when a servant commits a sin and then is afflicted with hardship or tribulation in this world, Allah is more noble than to punish him a second time.'

Indeed, from where do you know that another is more disobedient than you? Then perhaps his punishment has been delayed to the Hereafter, while your punishment was hastened in this world [dunya]. So why do you not thank Allah, the Exalted, for that? And this is the third aspect of thankfulness: that there is no punishment except that it is conceivable for it to be delayed to the Hereafter. And the afflictions of this world are consoled by other means which lessen the affliction, so its impact is lightened. But the affliction of the Hereafter is everlasting, and even if it were not everlasting, there is no way to lighten it through consolation, for the means of consolation are completely cut off in the Hereafter for those being punished. And for the one whose punishment was hastened in this world, he is not punished a second time, for the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: "Indeed, when a servant commits a sin and is afflicted by hardship or tribulation in this world, Allah is more generous than to punish him a second time." The fourth: that this affliction and tribulation was written for him in the Mother of the Book, and it was inevitable that it would reach him. And it has reached him, and the matter is concluded, and he is relieved of some of it or all of it. So this is a blessing [ni'mah]. The fifth: that its reward is greater than it. For the afflictions of this world are pathways to the Hereafter from two aspects: The first aspect is that by which the bitter medicine is a blessing for the sick, and the prevention from the means of play is a blessing for the child. For if he were left to his play, it would prevent him from knowledge [ilm] and refinement, and he would lose his entire life. Likewise, wealth, family, relatives, and limbsâ€”even the eye, which is the most precious of thingsâ€”can be a cause of a person's ruin in some circumstances. Indeed, the intellect [aql], which is the most precious of matters, can be a cause of his ruin. Tomorrow, the atheists will wish they had been insane or children and had not used their intellects concerning the religion of Allah, the Exalted. So there is nothing from these means found in a servant except that it is conceivable for there to be in it a religious good. So he must think well of Allah, the Exalted, and assume the good in it, and thank Him for it. For the wisdom [hikmah] of Allah is vast, and He is more knowledgeable of the welfare of His servants than the servants themselves. And tomorrow, the servants will thank Him for the tribulations when they see Allah's reward for the tribulations, just as the child, after attaining intellect and maturity, thanks his teacher and his father for striking him and disciplining him when he perceives the fruit of what he gained from the discipline. And the tribulation from Allah, the Exalted, is a discipline and a care for His servants more complete and abundant than the care of fathers for their children. It has been narrated: "A man said to the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him: 'Advise me.' He said: 'Do not suspect Allah concerning anything He has decreed for you.'" And "He, peace be upon him, looked to the sky and laughed. He was asked, and he said: 'I marvel at the decree of Allah, the Exalted, for the believer. If He decrees ease for him, he is content and it is good for him. And if He decrees hardship for him, he is content and it is good for him.'" The second aspect: that the head of the destructive sins is the love of this world [dunya], and the head of the means of salvation is the turning away of the heart [qalb] from the abode of delusion. And the uninterrupted flow of blessings in accordance with desire, without being mixed with tribulation and affliction, gives rise to the heart's contentment [tuma'ninah] with this world and its means, and its familiarity with it, until it becomes like Paradise in his sight. So his tribulation becomes immense at the time of death due to his separation from it. And when afflictions befall him frequently, his heart is agitated away from this world, and he does not find tranquility in it, nor familiarity with it, and it becomes a prison upon him. And his salvation from it becomes the utmost pleasure, like deliverance from prison. And for that reason, he, peace be upon him, said: "This world is the prison of the believer and the paradise of the disbeliever." And the disbeliever [kafir] is everyone who turns away from Allah, the Exalted, and desires nothing but the life of this world, and is content with it and finds tranquility in it. And the believer [mu'min] is everyone whose heart is severed from this world, intensely yearning to depart from it. And disbelief [kufr] is partly apparent and partly hidden. And according to the measure of love for this world in the heart, hidden polytheism [shirk] flows into it. Indeed, the absolute monotheist [muwahhid] is the one who loves nothing but the One True God. Therefore, in the tribulation there are blessings from this aspect, so it is obligatory to rejoice in it. As for the feeling of pain, it is inevitable. And that is akin to your joy when in need of cupping, with someone who performs your cupping for free, or gives you a beneficial, bitter medicine for free. For you feel pain and you rejoice. So you are patient with the pain and you thank him for the cause of the joy. So every tribulation in worldly matters is analogous to the medicine which pains in the present and benefits in the end. Indeed, whoever enters the abode of a king for a visit, knowing he will leave it without fail, and sees a beautiful face that will not leave with him from the abode, that is a calamity and a tribulation upon him, because it causes him to become familiar with a dwelling in which he cannot remain. And if there were a danger for him in remaining, that the king might become aware of him and punish him, and something he disliked befell him that repelled him from remaining, that would be a blessing for him. And this world is an abode. People have entered it through the door of the womb, and they will leave it through the door of the grave. So everything that confirms their familiarity with the abode is a tribulation, and everything that agitates their hearts away from it and severs their familiarity with it is a blessing. So whoever knows this, it is conceivable from him that he gives thanks for the tribulations. And whoever does not know these blessings in the tribulation, thankfulness is not conceivable from him, for thankfulness necessarily follows the knowledge [ma'rifah] of the blessing. And whoever does not believe that the reward for the affliction is greater than the affliction, thankfulness for the affliction is not conceivable from him.

And if not for the favor of Allah upon you and His mercy, not one of you would have been pure, ever, but Allah purifies whom He wills, and Allah is Hearing and Knowing.

ğŸ“– Vol 4: Patience and Gratitude
As for guidance (Hidayah), there is no way for anyone to seek happiness except through it, because the inclination of the human being may be leaning toward what contains the rectification (Salah) of his Hereafter, but if he does not know what contains the rectification of his Hereafter until he thinks corruption (Fasad) is rectification, then from where will mere will benefit him? So there is no benefit in will, capability, and causes except after guidance. And for that reason, Allah the Exalted said: 'Our Lord who gave everything its creation then guided' (Quran 20:50). And He said: 'And were it not for the favor (Fadl) of Allah upon you and His mercy (Rahmah), none of you would ever have been purified (Zakka), but Allah purifies whom He wills' (Quran 24:21). And He (the Prophet) said: 'No one enters Paradise except by the mercy of Allah the Exalted, meaning by His guidance.' It was said: 'Not even you, O Messenger of Allah?' He said: 'Not even me.' And guidance has three stations: The first is knowledge of the path of good and evil, indicated by His saying: 'And We guided him to the two ways' (Quran 90:10). And Allah the Exalted has bestowed this upon all His servants, some of it through intellect (Aql) and some of it upon the tongue of the messengers. And for that reason, He said: 'And as for Thamud, We guided them, but they preferred blindness over guidance' (Quran 41:17). So the means of guidance are the Book, the messengers, and the insights (Basa'ir) of the intellects, and they are made available, and nothing prevents from them except envy (Hasad), arrogance (Kibr), love of the worldly life (Dunya), and the causes that blind the hearts (Qulub) even though they do not blind the sights. He said: 'For indeed, it is not the eyes that are blinded, but blinded are the hearts which are within the breasts' (Quran 22:46). And among the blinding things are familiarity (Ilf) and habit (Adah) and the love of adhering to them, and from it is the expression by His saying: 'Indeed, we found our fathers upon a religion' (Quran 43:22) the verse. And from arrogance and envy is the expression by His saying: 'And they said, "Why was this Quran not sent down upon a great man from one of the two cities?"' (Quran 43:31) and His saying: 'A man from among us, one, we should follow him?' (Quran 54:24). So these blinding things are what prevented guidance, and the second guidance is beyond this general guidance, and it is that which Allah the Exalted extends to the servant.

Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

Vol 2: Etiquette of Companionship
Abdullah said: 'You have neither disciplined properly nor preserved the sanctity. Indeed, it is incumbent upon the Imam when a prescribed punishment (Hadd) reaches him to implement it, and Allah is Forgiving (Afuw) and loves forgiveness (Al-'Afw).' Then he recited: 'And let them pardon and overlook. Do you not love that Allah should forgive you? And Allah is Forgiving, Merciful.' Then he said: 'I remember the first man whose hand the Prophet (peace be upon him) amputated - a thief was brought and he amputated his hand, and it was as if his face was saddened. They said: "O Messenger of Allah, it seems you disliked amputating him." He said: "What prevents me? Do not be helpers to the devils against your brother." They said: "Why did you not pardon him?" He said: "It is incumbent upon the ruler when a prescribed punishment (Hadd) reaches him to implement it. Indeed, Allah is Forgiving (Afuw) and loves forgiveness (Al-'Afw)." And he recited: "And let them pardon and overlook. Do you not love that Allah should forgive you? And Allah is Forgiving, Merciful."'

a.g: Indeed, those who [falsely] accuse chaste, unaware and believing women are cursed in this world and the Hereafter; and they will have a great punishment
On a Day when their tongues, their hands and their feet will bear witness against them as to what they used to do.
That Day, Allah will pay them in full their deserved recompense, and they will know that it is Allah who is the perfect in justice.

Evil words are for evil men, and evil men are [subjected] to evil words. And good words are for good men, and good men are [an object] of good words. Those [good people] are declared innocent of what the slanderers say. For them is forgiveness and noble provision.
O you who have believed, do not enter houses other than your own houses until you ascertain welcome and greet their inhabitants. That is best for you; perhaps you will be reminded.

Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

Vol 2: Etiquette of Companionship
And it was narrated that Umar (may Allah be pleased with him) was patrolling in Medina at night when he heard the voice of a man in a house singing, so he climbed over the wall to him and found him with a woman and with wine. He said: 'O enemy of Allah, did you think that Allah would conceal you while you are upon disobedience?' He replied: 'And you, O Commander of the Believers, do not hasten, for if I have disobeyed Allah in one matter, you have disobeyed Allah in three matters. Allah the Exalted said: 'And do not spy' (Quran 49:12), and you have spied. And Allah the Exalted said: 'And it is not righteousness that you come to houses from their backs' (Quran 2:189), and you have climbed over the wall to me. And Allah the Exalted said: 'Do not enter houses other than your houses until you seek permission and greet their people' (Quran 24:27), and you have entered my house without permission and without greeting.' Umar (may Allah be pleased with him) said: 'Do you have any good if I pardon you?' He said: 'Yes, by Allah, O Commander of the Believers, if you pardon me, I will never return to the like of it ever.' So he pardoned him and left, abandoning him.

Vol 2: Enjoining Good and Forbidding Evil
And we have mentioned it in the Book of the Etiquettes of Companionship, and likewise what was narrated that Umar (may Allah be pleased with him) climbed over the wall of a man's house and saw him in a reprehensible state, so he rebuked him. The man said: 'O Commander of the Believers, if I have disobeyed Allah in one aspect, you have disobeyed Him in three aspects.' He said: 'And what are they?' He said: 'Allah the Exalted has said: "And do not spy" (Quran 49:12), and you have spied. And He said: "And enter houses from their doors" (Quran 2:189), and you have climbed over from the roof. And He said: "O you who have believed, do not enter houses other than your houses until you ascertain familiarity and greet their people" (Quran 24:27), and you did not greet.' So Umar left him and stipulated repentance upon him. And for that reason, Umar consulted the Companions (may Allah be pleased with them) while he was on the pulpit and asked them about the Imam if he witnesses a wrong with his own eyes, does he have the right to establish the prescribed punishment for it? Ali (may Allah be pleased with him) indicated that this is dependent upon two just witnesses, so one is not sufficient for it. And we have mentioned these reports in clarifying the right of the Muslim from the Book of the Etiquettes of Companionship, so we do not repeat them.

And the veils called lights are not intended to be the light perceived by the sight (Basar), but rather what is intended by the saying of The Exalted: 'Allah is the Light (Nur) of the heavens and the earth. Then let us pass over these meanings, for they are outside the knowledge of practice (Ilm al-Mu'amalah), and none reaches their realities except the unveiling (Kashf) that follows pure thought (Fikr), and few are those for whom its door opens. What is made easy for the masses of creation is thought (Fikr) in what benefits in the knowledge of practice (Ilm al-Mu'amalah), and that too is among what abounds in benefit and magnifies its usefulness. So these four functions, meaning supplication (Du'a), remembrance (Dhikr), recitation (Qira'ah), and thought (Fikr), should be the function of the seeker (Murid) after the dawn prayer, indeed in every session (Wird) after completing the function of prayer, for after prayer there is no function except these four. And one strengthens in that by taking his weapon and shield, and fasting (Sawm) is the shield that constricts the channels of the enemy Satan who diverts him from the path of guidance. And after the rising of dawn, there is no prayer except the two rak'ahs of Fajr and the obligatory dawn prayer until sunrise. The intelligent ones and possessors of insight, their hearts (Qalb) are "like a niche containing a lamp, the lamp in a glass, the glass as if it were a brilliant star, lit from a blessed olive tree, neither of the east nor of the west, whose oil would almost glow even if untouched by fire. So the intelligent ones are those whom Allah intended to guide, so He expanded their chests for Islam and guidance, and the deluded ones are those whom Allah intended to mislead, so He made their chests tight and constricted as if they were climbing into the sky.

Indeed, know that the honor of the intellect [al-'aql] is a matter needing no forced effort to reveal, especially since the honor of knowledge [al-'ilm] has already become apparent through the intellect. The intellect is the source [manba'] of knowledge, its point of emergence [matla'], and its foundation [asas]. Knowledge flows from it as fruit flows from a tree, as light [nur] flows from the sun, and as sight flows from the eye. How then can that which is the means to felicity in this world [al-dunya] and the Hereafter [al-akhirah] not be honored? Or how can there be doubt concerning it, when even the beast, with its deficient discernment, holds the intellect in awe? Indeed, the greatest of beasts in body, the fiercest in savagery, and the strongest in power, when it sees the form of a human, holds him in awe and fears him due to its sensing his mastery over it, because of what he is specifically endowed withâ€”the perception of stratagems. For this reason, the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "The elder [al-shaykh] among his people is like a prophet among his nation." This is not due to the abundance of his wealth, nor the greatness of his person, nor the increase of his strength, but rather due to the increase of his experience, which is the fruit of his intellect. For this reason, you see the Turks, the Kurds, the uncouth Bedouins, and the rest of creationâ€”despite the proximity of their station to the rank of beastsâ€”honoring the elders by nature. And for this reason, when many of the stubbornly defiant intended to kill the Messenger of God, peace and blessings be upon him, and their eyes fell upon him and were adorned by his noble countenance, they were in awe of him. And there appeared to them what used to gleam upon the brocade of his face from the light [nur] of prophethood, even though that was inwardly hidden within the inwardness of the intellect. Thus, the honor of the intellect is perceived by necessity. The intent here is only to relate what has come in the reports and verses concerning the mention of its honor. God has named it a light [nur] in His saying, the Exalted: "God is the Light of the heavens and the earth. The parable of His Light is as a niche..." And He named the knowledge [al-'ilm] derived from it a spirit [ruh], a revelation [wahy], and a life [hayah]. Thus He, the Exalted, said: "And thus have We revealed to you a spirit from Our command..." And He, the Glorified, said: "Or one who was dead, and We gave him life and made for him a light by which he walks among the people..." And wherever light [nur] and darkness [zulmah] are mentioned, He intends by them knowledge [al-'ilm] and ignorance [al-jahl], like His saying: "He brings them out from darknesses into the light." And the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "O people, comprehend from your Lord, and counsel one another with the intellect [al-'aql] so that you may recognize what you have been commanded and what you have been forbidden. And know that it will aid you before your Lord. And know that the possessor of intellect [al-'aqil] is he who obeys God, even if he is ugly in appearance, insignificant in importance, lowly in station, and shabby in attire. And the ignorant one [al-jahil] is he who disobeys God, the Exalted, even if he is beautiful in appearance, great in importance, noble in station, handsome in attire, eloquent and fluent in speech. For the monkeys and the swine are more possessors of intellect [a'qal] with God, the Exalted, than one who disobeys Him. And do not be deceived by the honor the people of this world [ahl al-dunya] give them, for they are among the losers."

And indeed, his oil which was in the niche of his heart (Qalb) was almost illuminating even if fire had not touched it. Then when knowledge (Ilm) blew into it with its intensity, his oil ignited and became light upon light. So knowledge said to him: 'Seize now this opportunity and open your sight (Basar) so that perhaps you may find guidance upon the fire.' So he opened his sight and the divine pen (Qalam) was unveiled to him. And behold, it was as knowledge had described it in transcendence (Tanzih) - not from wood nor reed, nor does it have a head nor tail, and it writes perpetually in the hearts (Qulub) of all humans all kinds of knowledge (Ulum); and as if it has in every heart a head while having no head. So he finished from it in wonder and said: 'Excellent is the companion knowledge, so may Allah reward him on my behalf with goodness, for now the truth of his reports about the attributes of the pen has become clear to me; for I see it as a pen not like pens.' At this point, he bid farewell to knowledge and thanked it, and said: 'My stay with you and my seeking from you has been long, and I am determined to travel to the presence of the pen and ask it about its affair.' So he traveled to it and said to it: 'What is with you, O pen, that you perpetually inscribe in the hearts (Qulub) from the knowledge (Ulum) what sends the intentions (Iradat) to the persons of decree (Qadar) and diverts them to the decreed matters (Maqdurat)?' It said: 'Or have you forgotten what you saw in the world of dominion (Mulk) and testimony (Shahadah) and heard from the answer of the pen when you asked it and it referred you to the hand?' He said: 'I have not forgotten that.' It said: 'So my answer is like its answer.' He said: 'How, and you do not resemble it?' The pen said: 'Have you not heard that Allah created Adam upon His image?' He said: 'Yes.' It said: 'So ask about my affair the one who is cast.'

Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

Vol 2: Etiquette of Earning a Livelihood
The third is that the market of the worldly life (Dunya) prevents him from the market of the Hereafter (Akhirah), and the markets of the Hereafter are the mosques. Allah the Exalted said: 'Men whom neither trade nor sale distracts from the Remembrance (Dhikr) of Allah and the establishment of prayer and giving of zakah.' And Allah the Exalted said: 'In houses which Allah has ordered to be raised and in which His Name is remembered. He is glorified therein in the mornings and the evenings.' So it is necessary to make the beginning of the day until the time of entering the market for his Hereafter, so he should frequent the mosque and be consistent in the regular litanies (Awrad). Umar, may Allah be pleased with him, used to say to the merchants: 'Make the beginning of your day for your Hereafter, and what comes after it for your worldly life.' And the righteous predecessors (Salaf) used to make the beginning of the day and its end for the Hereafter, and the middle for trade. And none would sell porridge and heads in the morning except the children and the protected people (Dhimmis) because they were in the mosques afterwards. And in the report: 'When the angels ascend with the record of the servant, and in it at the beginning of the day and at its end is the Remembrance (Dhikr) of Allah and good, Allah expiates for him what is between them of evil deeds.' A hadith: 'When the angels ascend with the record of the servant, and at the beginning of the day and its end is remembrance and good, Allah expiates what is between them of evil deeds.' Abu Ya'la narrated it from the hadith of Anas with a weak chain, with its meaning. And in the report: 'The angels of the night and the angels of the day meet at the rising of dawn and at the Asr prayer, and Allah the Exalted says, and He knows best about them: "How did you leave My servants?" They say: "We left them while they were praying, and we came to them while they were praying." Then Allah, glorified and exalted, says: "I bear witness to you that I have forgiven them."' A hadith: 'The angels of the night and the angels of the day meet at the rising of dawn and at the Asr prayer, and Allah says, and He knows best: "How did you leave My servants?"'

In summary, the cause of people's destruction is their greed for the worldly life (Dunya), and the cause of their greed for the worldly life (Dunya) is the stomach and the private parts, and the cause of the desire of the private parts is the desire of the stomach. And in reducing eating there is what cuts off all these conditions, and they are the gates of the Fire, and in cutting them off is the opening of the gates of Paradise, as he (the Prophet) said: 'Persist in knocking on the gate of Paradise with hunger.' So whoever is content with a loaf of bread each day becomes content in all other desires as well, and becomes free, and becomes independent of people, and rests from toil, and devotes himself to the worship of Allah the Exalted and the trade of the Hereafter, thus he will be among those whom trade and sale do not distract from the Remembrance (Dhikr) of Allah. And they are not distracted only because of their independence from it through contentment (Qana'a), whereas the needy one is inevitably distracted by it.

ğŸ“– Vol 3: Condemnation of Status and Ostentation
And whoever does not have the foundation of the knowledge of Allah the Exalted has no hope in this light, so he remains like one whose likeness is in the darknesses, not exiting from them, rather "like darknesses in a deep sea covered by a wave from above it a wave from above it a cloud, darknesses some of them above others." Therefore, there is no happiness except in the knowledge of Allah the Exalted. As for what is other than that from the knowledges, among them is what has no benefit at all, like the knowledge of poetry and the lineages of the Arabs and others, and among them is what has benefit in assisting towards the knowledge of Allah the Exalted, like the knowledge of the language of the Arabs, the interpretation (Tafsir), jurisprudence (Fiqh), and reports (Akhbar). For the knowledge of the language of the Arabs assists in knowing the interpretation of the Quran, and the knowledge of the interpretation assists in knowing what is in the Quran from the manner of the acts of worship and works that benefit the purification of the Soul (Tazkiyat al-Nafs), and the knowledge of the way of purifying the Soul (Tazkiyat al-Nafs) benefits the preparedness of the Soul (Nafs) for accepting the guidance to the knowledge of Allah, the Majestic and Exalted, as He the Exalted said: "Indeed successful is he who purifies it (Zakaha)" and He the Mighty and Majestic said: "And those who strive in Us, We will surely guide them to Our ways." So the totality of these knowledges is like the means to the realization of the knowledge of Allah the Exalted, and indeed the perfection is in the knowledge of Allah and the knowledge of His attributes and His actions, and it encompasses all the knowledges surrounding the existents since all the existents are from His actions. So whoever knows them from the aspect that they are the action of Allah the Exalted, and from the aspect of their connection to the Power (Qudrah), the Will (Iradah), and the Wisdom (Hikmah), then they are from the completion of the knowledge of Allah the Exalted. And this is the ruling of the perfection of knowledge we have mentioned, even if it is not suitable for the rulings of ignorance and ostentation, but we have presented it for the completion of the divisions of perfection.

ğŸ“– Vol 3: Condemnation of Self-Delusion
The intelligent ones and possessors of insight, their hearts (Qulub) are "like a niche containing a lamp, the lamp in a glass, the glass as if it were a brilliant star, lit from a blessed olive tree, neither of the east nor of the west, whose oil would almost glow even if untouched by fire; light upon light." And the deluded ones, their hearts (Qulub) are "like layers of darkness in a deep sea covered by waves, upon which are waves, above which are clouds; layers of darkness, one above another; when he puts out his hand, he can hardly see it. And he for whom Allah has not made light, for him there is no light." So the intelligent ones are those whom Allah intended to guide, so He expanded their chests for Islam and guidance, and the deluded ones are those whom Allah intended to lead astray, so He made their chests tight and constricted as if they were climbing into the sky.

a.g: Do you not see that Allah is exalted by whomever is within the heavens and the earth and [by] the birds with wings spread [in flight]? Each [of them] has known his [means of] prayer and exalting [Him], and Allah is Knowing of what they do.
And to Allah belongs the dominion of the heavens and the earth, and to Allah is the destination.

Do you not see that Allah drives clouds? Then He brings them together, then He makes them into a mass, and you see the rain emerge from within it. And He sends down from the sky, mountains [of clouds] within which is hail, and He strikes with it whom He wills and averts it from whom He wills. The flash of its lightening almost takes away the eyesight.
Allah alternates the night and the day. Indeed in that is a lesson for those who have vision.

The hungry person in the absence of food is more capable of patience than when delicious, tasty foods are present before him and he has power over them. a.g: Never think that the disbelievers are causing failure [to Allah] upon the earth. Their refuge will be the Fire - and how wretched the destination.

O you who have believed, let those whom your right hands possess and those who have not [yet] reached puberty among you ask permission of you [before entering] at three times: before the dawn prayer and when you put aside your clothing [for rest] at noon and after the night prayer. [These are] three times of privacy for you. There is no blame upon you nor upon them beyond these [periods], for they continually circulate among you - some of you, among others. Thus does Allah make clear to you the verses; and Allah is Knowing and Wise.
And when the children among you reach puberty, let them ask permission [at all times] as those before them have done. Thus does Allah make clear to you His verses; and Allah is Knowing and Wise.

And women of post-menstrual age who have no desire for marriage - there is no blame upon them for putting aside their outer garments [but] not displaying adornment. But to modestly refrain [from that] is better for them. And Allah is Hearing and Knowing.

There is not upon the blind [any] constraint nor upon the lame constraint nor upon the ill constraint nor upon yourselves when you eat from your [own] houses or the houses of your fathers or the houses of your mothers or the houses of your brothers or the houses of your sisters or the houses of your father's brothers or the houses of your father's sisters or the houses of your mother's brothers or the houses of your mother's sisters or [from houses] whose keys you possess or [from the house] of your friend. There is no blame upon you whether you eat together or separately. But when you enter houses, give greetings of peace upon each other - a greeting from Allah, blessed and good. Thus does Allah make clear to you the verses [of ordinance] that you may understand.

And Malik was more open (absat) and of better character than him, so Al-Hasan entered and said: 'O Muwaylik, this is how we used to be - we did not feel shy (yahtashim) with each other until you and your companions appeared.' And he indicated by this that openness (al-inbisat) in the houses of brothers (ikhwan) is from the purity (safa') in brotherhood (ukhuwwah). How could it not be, when Allah the Exalted has said: 'or your friend (sadiqikum)' and said: 'or what you possess the keys (mafatih) of it' - since a brother would give the keys (mafatih) of his house to his brother and delegate to him the disposal as he wishes, and his brother would feel constrained (yataharraj) about eating due to the ruling of piety (taqwa) until Allah the Exalted revealed this verse and permitted them in openness (al-inbisat) in the food of brothers (ikhwan) and true friends (asdiqa').

Indeed, if you are silent, he begins with you. And if a calamity befalls you, he consoles you. He is a companion who, if you speak, confirms your speech. And if you two attempt a matter, he commands you. And if you two dispute, he prefers you. Thus, it is as if He has gathered with this all the rights of companionship [á¹£uá¸¥ba] and stipulated that one be established in all of them. Ibn Aktham said: Al-Ma'mun said: "Explain this." So it was said to him: "Do you know why He enjoined him with that?" He said: "No." It was said: "Because He intended that he not accompany anyone." And some of the people of refinement [adab] said: "Do not accompany from among people except one who conceals your secret and covers your fault, who is with you in adversities, who prefers you with desirable things, who spreads your good and folds away your bad. If you do not find him, then accompany none but your own soul." And 'Ali, may God be pleased with him, said: "Your true brother is he who is with you, and he who harms himself to benefit you, and who, when the times of doubt [rayb] rend you asunder, scatters his own gathering to gather you." And some of the scholars said: "Accompany only one of two men: a man from whom you learn something concerning the matter of your religion [dÄ«n], so he benefits you; or a man whom you teach something concerning the matter of his religion, so he accepts from you. As for the third, flee from him." And some of them said: "People are four. One is sweet all of him, so one is not sated with him. Another is bitter all of him, so he is not eaten from. Another has sourness in him, so take from this one before he takes from you. And another has saltiness in him, so take from him only at the time of need." And Ja'far al-Sadiq, may God be pleased with him, said: "Do not accompany five: the liar [kadhdhÄb], for you are from him upon delusion, and he is like the mirage, bringing the distant near to you and making the near distant from you; and the fool [aá¸¥maq], for you are not from him upon anythingâ€”he intends to benefit you but harms you; and the miser [bakhÄ«l], for he cuts you off at your most needy time for him; and the coward [jabÄn], for he delivers you and flees at the time of severity; and the immoral one [fÄsiq], for he sells you for a morsel or less than it." It was said: "And what is less than it?" He said: "The covetousness for it, then he does not attain it." And al-Junayd said: "That an immoral one of good character accompany me is more beloved to me than that a reciter of bad character accompany me." And Ibn Abi al-Hawari said: "My teacher Abu Sulayman said to me: 'O Ahmad, accompany only one of two men: a man you find ease with in the matter of your worldly life [dunyÄ], or a man you increase with and benefit from in the matter of your Hereafter [Äkhira]. And occupation with other than these two is great folly.'" And Sahl ibn 'Abdullah said: "Avoid the companionship of three from the types of people: the tyrannical heedless ones, the reciters who are hypocrites, and the ignorant Sufis." And know that most of these statements do not encompass all the purposes of companionship. The encompassing is what we have mentioned from observing the intentions [maqÄá¹£id] and observing the conditions [shurÅ«á¹­] in addition to them. For what is stipulated for companionship in the intentions of the worldly life is not stipulated for his companionship in the Hereafter and brotherhood. As Bishr said: "Brothers are three: a brother for your Hereafter, a brother for your worldly life, and a brother for your solace. And these intentions rarely gather in one; rather, they are dispersed among a group, so the conditions are inevitably dispersed among them." And Al-Ma'mun said: "Brothers are three. One of them is like nourishmentâ€”one cannot do without him. Another is like medicineâ€”he is needed at a time, not at all times. The third is like a diseaseâ€”he is not needed at all, but the servant may be tested with him. And he is the one in whom there is no solace and no benefit." And it has been said: "The likeness of the totality of people is like trees and plants. Among them is what has shade but no fruitâ€”this is like one who is benefited from in the worldly life, not the Hereafter, for the benefit of the worldly life is like a shade, swiftly vanishing. And among them is what has fruit but no shadeâ€”this is like one who is suitable for the Hereafter, not the worldly life. And among them is what has fruit and shade together. And among them is what has neither one of them, like the thorny shrub that tears clothes, with no taste in them and no drink." And its like from the animals is the mouse and the scorpion, as God, the Exalted, said: "He calls to one whose harm is closer than his benefit. How wretched the protector and how wretched the associate!" And the poet said: "People are diverse; if you taste them, they are not equal, just as trees are not equal. This one has sweet fruit, its taste pleasant, and that one has no taste and no fruit." So if one does not find a companion to befriend and benefit from for one of these intentions, then solitude [waá¸¥da] is better for him. Abu Dharr, may God be pleased with him, said: "Solitude is better than the bad companion, and the good companion is better than solitude." And it is narrated as elevated: "As for religiosity [diyÄna] and the absence of immorality [fisq], God, the Exalted, has said: 'And follow the way of him who turns to Me.'" And because witnessing immorality and the immoral ones makes the matter of disobedience light upon the heart [qalb] and nullifies the heart's aversion from it. Sa'id ibn al-Musayyib said: "Do not look at the wrongdoers, lest your deeds be rendered vain." How is it when God, the Exalted, has said: "Or your friend" and said: "Or what you possess its keys"? For the brother would hand over the keys of his house to his brother and delegate to him disposal as he wished. And his brother would be scrupulous about eating due to the ruling of piety [taqwÄ], until God, the Exalted, revealed this verse and gave them permission to be at ease with the food of brothers and friends.

a.g: The believers are only those who believe in Allah and His Messenger and, when they are [meeting] with him for a matter of common interest, do not depart until they have asked his permission. Indeed, those who ask your permission, [O Muhammad] - those are the ones who believe in Allah and His Messenger. So when they ask your permission for something of their affairs, then give permission to whom you will among them and ask forgiveness for them of Allah. Indeed, Allah is Forgiving and Merciful.

Do not make [your] calling of the Messenger among yourselves as the call of one of you to another. Already Allah knows those of you who slip away, concealed by others. So let those beware who dissent from the Prophet's order, lest fitnah strike them or a painful punishment.

Unquestionably, to Allah belongs whatever is in the heavens and earth. Already He knows that upon which you [stand] and [knows] the Day when they will be returned to Him and He will inform them of what they have done. And Allah is Knowing of all things.
